newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian shares seen rebounding after correction.
newsitem.headline: Indian shares seen rebounding after correction.

text.p: Buoyant foreign fund inflows are expected to help volatile Indian shares rebound this week after a technical correction, analysts said.
"The present correction could continue further to 4,250 levels by Tuesday, before the market stages a strong recovery," said the brokerage Khandwala Securities Ltd.

The benchmark Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) index closed last week in negative territory for the first time since the week ended May 23. The 30-share BSE index closed 1.84 points lower at 4,321.98 after soaring to a 33-month high of 4,448.06.
Analysts said they saw no slow down in foreign portfolio funds pumping cash into Indian equities, which have been among the best performing emerging markets in 1997.
They expect foreign inflows of at least $310 million in July. Net foreign institutional investments were $57 million from July 1-9 -- against $362.9 million in June.
A booming Wall Street and falling gold prices attracted more money into shares, equity strategist Arun Kejriwal said.
"Falling gold prices and the fear of holding on to gold is generating invisable funds," he said. "Some of the windfall gains from U.S. markets are also coming to emerging markets."
He said the stock to look at this week was State Bank of India, which would come out of a three-week, no-delivery period when the company's books are closed for dividend payments.
Indications of a pick-up in economic activity was another crucial factor driving Indian shares higher, analysts said.
"Real non-food credit growth has picked up since April," NatWest Markets said in a report. "After persistently falling for about 10 months, real credit has bottomed out..."
It said the growth in non-food credit normally leads growth in manufacturing by about two months.
In the next few weeks, analysts expect the benchmark Bombay index to beat its peak of 4,643.31 set on September 12, 1994.
"That's very possible," said R. Balakrishnan, president of brokerage Dil Vikas Finance Ltd. "But I refuse to believe this is backed by fundamentally sound factors."
He said the upsurge was largely due to demand-supply mismatches caused by strong demand in some 100 odd stocks and the lack of sellers.
"The market lacks depth," he said. "You pump in $300-$400 million and this market booms."

Indian stock markets have risen about 60 percent since hitting a three-year low in December 1996. Net foreign portfolio inflows during this period have totalled $1.2 billion, figures released by the market regulator show.
Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd, Glaxo, ITC and Reliance were some of the stocks that have more than doubled during this period, Balakrishnan said.

Shares of multinational firms preferred by foreign funds because of consistent returns and better quality of management have become expensive, with many trading at price-to-earnings multiples of 45 to 50, traders said.
Strategist Kejriwal said he was doubtful if this rally could be sustained.
"First-half company results could be a bombshell," he said. "We might see a correction phase ahead in October."
For the half year ending September 30, 1997, companies are expected to show flat growth though big cap firms would benefit from lower interest costs, analysts said.
